reviewText:
Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet surprised me. The game's story/setting is charming/quirky and I enjoyed it a lot more than I was expecting. There are quite a few funny moments in the game as well.  The story might not appeal to everyone but I enjoyed it quite a bit.

The puzzles are pretty clever and well designed. Unlike some point and click adventure games the puzzles aren't obtuse where you have to guess your ways to the correct answer. The game is just really well made.

I really only had two complaints with Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet. First the game is kind of on the shorter side. The game lasts around five to six hours. Since I was really enjoying the game I wish it was a little longer. The other problem is that for the most part I found the game to be kind of easy. You probably aren't going to be really challenged by the game.

Although not totally necessary, I would recommend playing the original game first. You won't be lost if you don't play the first game but the game does sometimes address things that happen in the first game so you might be slightly confused a couple times in the game. The original game can be found online for free.

If you like point and click adventure games I think you will enjoy Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet.

Note: I received a review copy from the developer but received no other compensation for this review.

Read My Full Review[www.geekyhobbies.com]

reviewText:
This game is like a cute younger sibling to Monkey Island.

I backed Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet on Kickstarter, because I was a fan of the previous Nelly Cootalot game. I loved the background art, but was skeptical on how well the new character designs were going to work. Playing the game, the character designs did really grow on me, so I'd say don't write it off if you have the same initial issue. The puzzles are typical for a point-and-click adventure, with nothing too challenging. Really, this game is about its great sense of humor. If you like your games to be a bit clever and adorable, this one is on point. It certainly is one of the punnier games I've played.

Also, Tom Baker as Sebastian is too charming. Such a great companion to have through the game.
voteText: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is quite clearly the product of someone with a passion for both adventure games and humor. Top notch production (with SUPERLATIVE voice acting and music), great puzzles and design, and wonderful story/characters with some of the funniest dialogue from a videogame yet. A must-play for any fan of this genre!\n\nEDIT: Just now officially completed the game, lemme tell you BIG SMILE ON MY FACE! I will say at around 5 or so hours it's a bit short, but in my own personal opinion it's better to go short than to outstay your welcome. This is gonna go down as one of my top of 2016 for sure, and I CANNOT WAIT for the next Nelly Cootalot game, fantastic effort all around, pick this game up today!

reviewText:
I'm really enjoying this game so far, I've played two hours (will update the review as I continue playing) and solved a few of the early puzzles. The puzzles so far are logical and the humor is great. The graphics are well done, it runs really well on Linux and the voice acting is very engaging, particularly Nelly and Sebastian. 9/10 so far.

Update: I completed the game after about 8 hours. Its a really fun game with lots of humour and a good story. The voice acting is really well done throughout and the hand drawn graphics suit the game and fit well with the story. Right clicking on all the clickable items results in some very funny descriptions. I would have liked the game to be longer, its a bit short and could be completed in about 6 hours if you don't fully explore all the areas. It has some replayability as the achievements are all actually achievable, so I will play through again to get the ones I missed.

Overall an enjoyable adventure game that would have been even better if it had a few more areas to explore and was a bit longer. 8/10.

reviewText:
This is a charming and surprising game, sufficiently so it's prompted me to create my first Steam review. I purchased it as a Kickstarter backer and I was hoping for an amusing little adventure for the low price I paid, but was prepared for disappointment (I've backed Godus, Massive Chalice, Planetary Annihilation after all...).

I didn't expect to be so relaxed and smiling within a couple of minutes of starting, or the quality of voice acting to be so high (Doctor Who ! The main character's great, also).

It's not a hard game - you won't be stuck for hours in this one trying to collect Tea, and No Tea simultaneously - but it is a labour of love that's produced a charming and fun adventure with a consistent and pleasant style of its own.

Overall Nelly Cootalot is to adventure games and Kickstarter, what FTL is to roguelikes and Kickstarter.

reviewText:
A gem of a game.  I've been slowly working my wy through Nelly Cootalot, and thoroughly enjoying the experience.  The classic Lucas Arts games of the 90s set a tremendously high bar for point and click adventures, and I'm always a little trepidatious when starting to play a new one.  Thankfully, Nelly nails all the key elements that a good point a click adventure needs.

The hand drawn artwork is lovely throughout.  It looks like a lot of time and love has been spent on all the backgrounds and characters.  The voice acting is generally of a high standard, and most importantly Nelly herself has great humour and charm with which she delivers her lines.

The puzzles are sometimes easy, sometimes tricky, and I haven't yet been stuck frustratingly on anything for too long.  Most importantly the game has oodles of humour, and the next laugh, chuckle or guffaw is never far away.

If you like your games funny, charming, and engrossing then this is one to pick up.

reviewText:
Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is the follow-up to the popular 2007 freeware adventure, Spoonbeaks Ahoy![www.adventuregamestudio.co.uk], which won five AGS Awards and was nominated for seven more. In this game, we're introduced to our heroine Nelly Cootalot in a tutorial set aboard the mailship Undeliverable. Here you'll learn how to interact with other characters, to examine, pick up and use items, and how to combine them in your inventory. This is also where you learn of the villanous Baron Widebeard's evil plans, which involves a fleet of hypnotised birds.

As a bird-lover and defender of adorable creatures, Nelly wants none of that, and sets off in pursuit of Widebeard to his last known location. In order to progress from there, you must figure out the Baron's next destination by correctly applying information from a log book to a wall chart of ship departures—a puzzle that is one of my favorites in the game. You also have to gain permission to leave the docks by helping the miserable Admiral Woebegone by solving a classic three trials" style branching puzzle.

Your next leg of the journey takes you to the main area of the game

reviewText: Fantastic, if short game.  Puzzles are all fairly logical, the game has a good sense of humor, and it's beautiful to look at.  A not to subtle love letter to Monkey Island play this if you loved those and want a nice, easy to play point and click you wont need to have a walkthrough to actually beat.

reviewText: I recived a code for this game prior to launch for review. Starting out, and not knowing about the history of Nelly Cootalot, I was skeptical. Although there were some hickups, and a few rough edges(Which I'm sure were pre-release, known issues), I really enjoyed my experience with the game, and was very excited to keep going. This game has a wide demographic in mind, and although I and a big fan of point and click games, I found the challange to be perfect, if a little easy at times. The puzzles are fair and some larger ones require actual problem solving, like the candle puzzle. The humor in the writing is alright. Although some jokes didn't stick, I didn't much mind. The voice acting was great and really added to my experience.\n\nIn short, if you like light hearted point and click adventures, or haven't played a Point and Click in a while, Nelly Cootalot and the Fowl Fleet is a great addition to your library. Some of the most fun I've had from a title this year.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PGjZE8PWoQE

Overview
There was a time when Nelly was somewhat of a great pirate. She saved the Spoonbeaks once upon a time but now she’s a lowly mail clerk on a mail ship. Her ol’ ghost pirate pal, Bloodbeard, shows up to let her know that her great enemy Widebeard is up to his old tricks again. This time he’s manipulating the Spoonbeaks and various other beards and using them to do his bidding. Now Nelly must find Widebeard and stop him before he releases his Fowl Fleet!

Visuals
Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is the sequel to an Adventure Game Studio title called Nelly Cootalot: Spoonbeaks Ahoy! While that game featured a hand drawn 2D style of gameplay. The Fowl Fleet is beautifully rendered in vibrant 3D visuals. The animations for the various characters and actions are simple but sweet. Don’t expect too much wacky movement outside of a few cut scenes and you should be golden.

The world of Nelly Cootalot likes to keep it simple, but there are still plenty of kicks to get out of the characters movements. One particularly humorous example is after Nelly helps a bird move to a new home, and he thanks her by giving her a hat full of his poop before sliding away into his new nest. It’s simple and sweet and adds a different sort of hilarity to the world.

Story
Nelly Cootalot is a comedic adventure title and it never stops reminding us. Nelly is gung-ho but completely dimwitted at the same time. She’s like a stupider version of Drax from Guardians of the Galaxy. She takes most anything people tell her literally, so she’ll end up asking ridiculous questions or won’t fully understand basic innuendo.

Luckily, a wide variety of the people she meets are quick to crack a few jokes or two. One of my favorite characters in the game is named, “Gusty Nethers.” Yeah… that’s right… Gusty Nethers. He also has a few other ridiculous names he starts to call himself over the course the game. Gusty is just one of many characters that don’t take themselves too seriously. It makes for some wonderful back and forth banter between Nelly and the various characters.

Sound
There are some downsides and most of it comes in the form of the voice acting. It’s not to say that the voice acting is bad, in fact a lot of it is great. It’s that the jokes fall flat because the timing or the emotion isn’t particularly perfect. Sometimes Nelly or another character will tell a joke and there is no oomph to it whatsoever. Other times there will be a witty back and forth and the timing of a joke is just not enough to evoke laughter. It’s the moments like these that are a bit of a drawback to The Fowl Fleet, because it’s filled with hit and miss jokes.

Gameplay
When it comes to the mechanics of the title. The team sought to make a game that isn’t just ham-fisted with combining items and clicking things. There are quite a few thoughtful puzzles in the game that think outside the box. Lots of the brainteasers rely on some well thought out and even nostalgic design choices. The enigma of it all functions by figuring out elements of a puzzle and piecing it altogether to create one cohesive part.

A sample of this is one of the first real puzzles, where Nelly has to figure out the route of a fleet of ships by studying a log. Using different days as a reference you have to piece together the name and location of a ship she has to board. There are a variation of moments like these that shirk the usual “Click on random things” design of most adventure titles. Nelly Cootalot gives me a Professor Layton vibe as it consistently gives us amusing and well-thought out puzzles to enjoy.

Nelly Cootalot may not be a particularly hard game, but how many Adventure games truly are? Most of them are difficult because you didn’t click the right objects, or you missed some dialogue that you can’t see again. Nelly Cootalot never leaves you lingering for too long on one of the many riddles. If you interact with the characters and observe the items, you’ll zip through the game without being tied down by boring pixel clicking.

I appreciate this, because I do enjoy the experience and the story of adventure games more than being stranded on Puzzle Island. I like to be challenged but not to the point where I’m stuck in one specific area for three hours because of something I didn’t notice. Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is middle of the road in difficulty and I’m perfectly fine with that.

Issues
I have some early build concerns that hopefully will be addressed in the retail version. The first area of the game is ripe with UI and scrolling problems. The item slot would occasionally stay on-screen which impeded my ability to interact with anything else. Also, there were times when the screen would stop scrolling and I couldn’t walk to an area I needed to visit.  This game doesn’t realize when you’re using dual-monitors and uses the secondary screen instead. I had to switch to single-screen settings if I wanted to record video of the game.

Conclusion
Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet started off as something I would have dismissed because it was trying too hard to be funny. It’s not until I ran into the first real puzzle before I said, “Hey, this is actually different for an adventure game.” Suddenly, I was hankering for the next new puzzle and engaged in solving any riddle that came my way.

I began to appreciate the simplistic animations and suddenly fell in love with the world of Nelly Cootalot. If you’re looking for an entertaining and different Adventure title, Nelly Cootalot might be the game with just enough charm to draw you in. Nelly is no Guybrush Threepwood, but she is certainly in a position to take over where he left off.

reviewText:
Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is great fun. The animation and art are wonderful and the voice acting was some of truly best I've ever heard. Having backed its Kickstarter ages ago, I was very well pleased with the money spent and I would have no qualms about backing them again.

It's only drawback for me is that it's rather short. I finished it in about 5.5 hours, and that's looking at every single thing.

I would certainly recommend it, though. It's puzzles are well plotted and are much more logical than a lot of adventure games of old, but on the easy side for anyone who's played many adventure games. I've been playing them for over 20 years and had very little trouble with any of them.

There were a couple of bugs that I noticed. The cursor doesn't always change once you take it off of an item and hover over a different one (for example, you look at Crow's Nest and then Roof, but the cursor will still say Crow's Nest, even though it gives you information on Roof if you click on it). The other bug is when Nelly is supposed to be walking up a hill behind a building. It looks as though she's walking up the front of the building instead.

The only other thing I would say is that if you want to have a go at getting all of the achievements, they aren't all working yet. The final one (the Timewaster, the one for having achieved all the others) doesn't show up, despite having all the other 19. I had enough pleasure in playing the game, though, that I will go back and play it again once that's fixed.

reviewText:
I’ve LP’d the previous installment[lparchive.org], Kickstarted the sequel, and was rather looking forward to this. Let’s break down my impressions, from least important to the most:

Graphics: I kinda miss the original hand-drawn look. It had a unique charm to it that the smoother and less unique 3d models lack.

Voicework: Quite good all around. Except from some British TV guy – apparently everyone were so excited to have him on that they forgot to check whether his voice fits the character.

Controls: Remarkably bad, by adventure game standards. Everything feels a bit sluggish and slow to react to commands. Whenever you try to click two items in quick succession (quick = within a second or two) the game is sure to get confused and randomly misapply your clicks.

Puzzle quality: Generally decent – moderately challenging at times, but logical and sensible. You never have to resort to random item combinations, your inventory is emptied of formerly useful items in regular intervals, and the big puzzle sets require just the right amount of thought. I got stuck on two separate occasions – one is a bit of accidental misinformation the developer promised to remove, while the other was a random piece of the puzzle stuck in a cluttered screen where it had no reason to be.
HOWEVER. There are mini-games scattered at regular intervals, and they are terrible at conveying their control schemes and victory conditions.

Writing quality: Maintains the quirky charm of the original, has a few laugh out loud moments every so often (helped by the voice work and decent comic timing). However, every so often you’ll get a random meme shoved in, not at all meshing with the overall writing style. The game has an “arrow to the knee” joke. In 2016(!)
Also, I think the ending and the airship section were severely cut during the production stage, and it SHOWS. Just a bit of a mess from the writing perspective.

Overall: 7/10. Cute and charming, if not a particularly innovative. It’s probably a bit too late to actually fix the ending into something coherent, but improving the controls, mini-game instructions and dumping the memes would bump the rating up to 8/10.
voteText: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Nelly Cootalot so thoroughly embraces its retro inspirations, that an uncharitable person might call it out-dated. However, it breezes along with such warm-hearted charm, boundless likability, and its none-more-British sense of humour that it's hard to criticise. It's populated with a cast of great characters, with the eponymous Nelly as the pirate heroine out to save all bird-kind from the schemes of her nemesis, Baron Widebeard. The puzzles are fair, logical, and satisfying to solve; you'll rarely spend time trying random inventory items with everything in sight and are unlikely to be forced to consult a walkthrough. Don't forget to consult your fowl companion, Sebastian, for some of the games funniest lines and hints if you lose track of what you're doing.\n\nThis game is an easy recommendation for fans of pirate adventures of yesteryear (you know the ones...) and point-and-click games in general. You'll spend your entire playthrough with a big smile on your face or your money back (maybe).

reviewText:
Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is a fairly straightforward game that does not make you stop and think too long about each puzzle or force you to combine items aimlessly to figure out what to do next. Your goals are simple, and the way to accomplish them is often hinted at with just an ounce of subtlety by dialogue or object descriptions. The first minigame was the only one I didn't really grasp, and I still made it on my first try with a lucky guess. The others could have used some explanation at least for using their interfaces like Daedalic did for the Deponia series, but trial and error doesn't punish you for failure, so you can just figure it out on your own.

The main selling point of the game would be its humor, which had me not only smile at the numerous puns but genuinely laugh out loud at some of the main character's quips. Nelly herself is another high point of the game with her endearing mix of lawlessness and cluelessness. Her remarks make you want to look at every object twice to make sure you hear all the clever little things she has to say about them.

Overall the game is a bit on the short side (a little over 5 hours for me), but a fun and relaxing interactive adventure throughout. Likely an excellent choice to introduce your kids to the genre!

reviewText:
Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is a funny point and click adventure that takes you along a unique story line in the shoes of a pirate girl names Nelly. Join her as she unlocks the mysteries of her past and present, her struggle to save the birds from a horrible fate and the world from an even worse one. One of the best voice acted games I’ve seen in a long time the humor will keep you laughing for hours to come.

Pros:

-	Beautiful scenes with a number of hidden objects just waiting to be found.
-	Voice acting is amazing and will immerse you into the gameplay with every turn of phrase.
-	Humor at every turn that is both silly, and cleaver.
-	Challenging puzzles to be solves that will use both imagination and cleverness to overcome.
-	A story line that is gripping and playfully funny.
-	Characters that are rich in personality and well written, causing you to grow attached to them and their fate quite easy.

Cons:

-	Haven’t found any yet.

In Conclusion, Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is a fantastic click and play game that measures up to the best of them, I highly recommend this game, well worth the price and will give hours of entertainment. 5 out of 5, and winner of the Dragon Games Award.
AC- Gamer

reviewText: First things first, I should mention that one of my friends was involved in the production of this game -- and voices a pompous sea bird -- and I've spent an afternoon playing Bomberman with both the creator of the game and Nelly Cootalot herself, or at least her inspiration and voice actor.\n\nNelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet is a comedic point and click adventure game about pirates. If you are now thinking Gosh
date: that's a bit like deciding to be a sprinter and challenging Usain Bolt to a race your first time out" then that's a bit weird that we both thought of that
recommended: but you'd be correct. The shadow of Monkey Island looms large over this game -- now I'm imagining a Lovecraft pastiche; The Shadow Over Monkey Island -- but not only does the script acknowledge the influence
hoursPlayed: Nelly Cootalot is strong enough to stand up to and apart from its illustrious predecessor.\n\nThe writing for the most part is strong
voteText: and the characters' personalties come across well
helpfulPercent: helped in no small part by good voice acting throughout. Nelly herself is a charming protagonist; everyone seems to like her
votesHelpful: and her cheerful approach to adventure is infectious. The main villains are a bit sketchy
votesTotal: and not in the appropriate sense of the word; I think they return from the original game in the series
votesFunny: but as I've not played that
commentsCount: their motivations and personalities seem a bit vague in this instalment. A new villain introduced in the middle section of the game comes across far better
column16: although again his motivations and connection to the main plot are somewhat unclear. Still
column17: it's Nelly and her friends who are most important and they are well-written and acted; aside from Nelly herself
column18: I was most impressed by her sidekick Sebastian
column20: 000: Fire Warrior" Baker. To be honest
column21: I was expecting someone of Sir Tom's prestige to sleepwalk through his role but he brings a lot of personality to Sebastian
column22: even though he has one of those voices that means you can never quite forget that there's an actor behind the character.\n\nThe game is funny
column23: and there's a varied approach to the jokes
column24: with plenty of references to films and games
column26: a dash of satire here and there
column27: and at least one bit of smutty innuendo
column28: although that last one doesn't land as well as it could have due to some clumsy back-pedalling. Some comments and reviews have claimed that the game is for children -- perhaps because of the art style -- but the latter joke suggests not
column29: and some of the references are going to go right over the heads of most kids
column30: unless they are showing Jack Nicholson films in primary schools these days.\n\nThe game looks good too. The trailers did look a bit ropey
column31: with a flat animation style reminiscent of Flash or a cheap CBeebies programme
column32: but the game itself looks much better. The character models look to be cel-shaded and that gives them a bit more weight
column33: and they are for the most part well-animated; it is a bit of a shame that they don't tend to do anything when Nelly isn't interacting with them
column34: but one has to remember that this isn't a multi-million pound game with a hundred-strong creative team behind it. That said
column35: it's a pleasant surprise when you spot a character making a small movement or gesture that must have added time to the production schedule and is irrelevant to wider game
column36: but helps to bring the character to life. It shows a dedication and craftsmanship that you don't often see in the aforementioned larger productions.\n\nI did encounter a couple of graphical glitches; during one part of the Guttering Howls section Nelly walks in front of and through something she should be behind
column37: and in the penultimate chapter the inventory panel goes a bit wonky
column38: but is still usable. I also had a bit of trouble with the game's interface being slow to register what was under the pointer
column39: although the mechanics worked as expected
column40: so it wasn't a major issue. I played the game on Linux Mint 17.3 and I don't know if these glitches are in every port.\n\nHeh
column41: "port". Like sailors. Heh.\n\nNelly Cootalot's puzzles are varied and often require different approaches and techniques to solve; even when they are of the give-item-A-to-person-B sort
column42: they are at least presented in novel ways so the game never gets dull. In terms of difficulty
column43: the puzzles are if not simple
column45: so you are never hunting for rogue pixels or throwing every item at every character
column46: hoping for the best.\n\nThat said if there is a flaw in Nelly Cootalot -- and to be fair
column47: it is the only thing I would consider a proper flaw -- it's the wider game and story logic surrounding the puzzles. On a few occasions I worked out the solution to a problem
column48: and had all the correct items in my inventory ready to go
column49: but I couldn't apply said solution because I hadn't gone to talk to someone -- often in another location -- who was supposed to give me the idea I'd already had. This led to frustration and -- in one case near the end of the game -- a suspicion that there was a game-breaking bug. On the plus side
column50: Sebastian is able to give hints about what to do next
column51: and in at least one case this helped resolve the impasse
column52: although in the latter instance I did end up roaming around clicking on everything and everyone until I spoke to the right person.\n\nCreator Alasdair Beckett-King is a jolly nice fellow -- and is not bad at Bomberman -- but it turns out he's quite good at making computer games too. I had great fun playing Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet and although it is short -- it can be completed in about five hours or so
column53: although getting the Steam achievements will take longer -- I think it is worth the £12 I paid for it. There are rough edges
column54: and places where I feel Alasdair and his team could have done a tiny bit more
column56: and I hope the game is enough of a success that we see more from him.\n\nIf you like point and click adventure games
column57: give this a try because you'll probably ike it. If you don't
column59: as it's charming and funny and may change your mind."

reviewText: A great game that I can highly recommend. Great graphics, great voice acting and an interesting and very amusing story.\n\nThe only issue I encountered is with one puzzle - amputation. The logic of the puzzle escaped me even after I looked up the solution and completed it. Completing the second part of the puzzle as others did it was not possible for me, I completed it by random clicking on the screen. Possibly my computer setup contributed this problem, although others reported having problems with this puzzle.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A lighthearted point-and-click adventure with interesting puzzles and a nice story.

The voice acting is superb and really lifts the game up and makes it come alive -- Tom Baker (my favourite Doctor Who) especially makes this something I enjoy.

If you like adventure games where the story is the focus more than the puzzles, then I think you will like this.

reviewText: It's a sweet and extremely well written game. Serriously, the puns and clever wordplay is at LucasArts-level, and that's a fantastic thing. Voice acting is spot on as well. I've played it in English and German, and the German translation is LucasArts-quality as well (with maybe one minor complaint about the voice actor of Confusius).\n\nThe puzzle design is mostly logical, with only a few adventure-game-y" ones. But that may also make the game a bit easy and short. But while it lasts

My 2 cents about this game:

- story: a bit childish but well written and full of horrible" puns =)
- main character: lovely and witty female protagonist
- voice acting and music: spot on
- visuals: eye candy
date:
could be from a children illustration book
- controls: double click to move to the next screen and interactable items highlight present which overcomes two the main drawbacks of the genre
- puzzles: not really chalenging - and there are plenty of clues - so this might be a good game to introduce point and clicks to younger players

... and I'm in the credits for which I am grateful. :)"

reviewText: Fantastic fun adventure game drawing on titles like Monkey Island and King's quest. The writing, visuals and voice acting are great - we were laughing out loud regularly. Took about 6 hours to complete and was well worth the money (we got it in the release sale). 8.5/10 let me know when there is a sequel!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Excellent indie game!  It's a bit of Monkey Island 1-3 all in one.  Nice puzzles although often easy especially during the final scene.  The ending felt a little rushed but that's just a budget/timing thing.  It'd be interesting to see what they could do with a real budget.

Overall, great game, great music and voice acting, great graphics/illustrations and great storytelling.

Go get Nelly Cootalot: The Fowl Fleet now!
